moves.1. e4: My opponent deviates from "book" on move 11, and rapidly falls into a Queen trap.
moves.1... e6 2. d4 d5 3. Nd2 c5 4. Ngf3 cxd4: White can afford to not retake the d-pawn yet and concentrate on an attack.
moves.7... Nf6 8. Nb3 Nc6 9. Qe2 Be7 10. Rd1 Q: So far book. Here Black does not forsee the strength of a5.
moves.12... Qc7 13. Nfxd4 Nxd4 14. Rxd4: White regains the pawn and is developing a strong attack.
moves.14... b6: This move, ...b6?? looks promising at first but Black fails to notice that the Queen is running out of squares.
moves.17... Qb8 18. Bxb8 Rxb8 19. Qe5: It is easy to look brilliant when you have won the Queen for a bishop. Here White remains aggressive to deny Black any counterplay.
moves.21... Nf6 22. Bc4: White now has a stranglehold on the position.
moves.25... h6 26. Rad1 Be7 27. Re1 Bc5 28. Rd: White has Black tied up, and needs to avoid any back rank mate threates as well as restrict the Knight.
moves.32... g5 33. Qa4 Bf8 34. Nd4 Nh5: This does not meet the threat.
moves.35. Nf5+ Kg6 36. Qc2 Ng7 37. Ne7+ Kf6 38: White has picked up even more material, and now seeks to checkmate.
